Environmental Barriers & Environmental Cleaning and Disinfection
Surfaces
Work surfaces are cleanable (i.e. non-porous)
Operatories and reprocessing areas are free of fabric-upholstery and carpeting
Operatory furnature and surfaces are in good repair and cleanable
Dental light lense/sheild is in good repair and cleanable
Treatment area surfaces are free of unecessary supplies and equipment
Clean supplies are protected from contamination/exposure
Posters are wipeable (i.e. laminated)
Surface barriers are replaced/removed with procedures to prevent contamination
Devices
Permanent devices (i.e. high volume suction, saliva ejectors, air/water syringes) are cleaned and covered between patient use
Contaminated permanent devices are disinfected between patient use
The operatory is inspected and cleaned/disinfected when necessary between patients
Cleaning Solutions
Cleaning solutions and disinfectants are used according to manufacturer’s instructions
Ready-to-use products are used or fresh cleaning solution is prepared, dated and discarded according to the manufacturer’s instructions
When in-house solutions are discarded, the containers and dispensinc mechanisms are cleaned and dried
Liquid products are not topped up
All materials and containers are labelled appropriately
If chemicals are decanted into smaller bottles, they are labelled appropriately
Non-disposable cleaning cloths and mop heads (e.g. microfibre) are laundered after each use and stored dry
Disinfectants have a Drug Identification Number (DIN) from Health Canada
Prior to disinfection, all visibly soiled surfaces are cleaned appropriately
Cleaning clothes are not double-dipped into cleaning solution
Surfaces
Dental surfaces and countertops not protected by barriers are cleaned and disinfected between each patient using a low-level disinfectant (LLD)
Sufficient contact time (i.e. "wet time") is allowed for disinfecting
If a surface has been visibly soiled with blood, a low-level disinfectant is used
Housekeeping surfaces (floors, walls, sinks) are regularly cleaned using a low-level disinfectant
Walls, blinds, and window curtains are cleaned when visibly dusty or soiled
Waste/Linen
Reusable linen is laundered between patient use
Soiled linen is contained in leak-proof bags
Waste and linen containers are not over-filled
Appropriate disposal of general medical waste (i.e. ordinary waste)
Appropriate disposal of regulated medical waste (i.e. according to local regulations)
Waste containers are covered in storage areas
Waterlines and Water Quality
Monitoring and records are maintained for dental equipment and water quality
Coolant/Irrigant water for non-surgical procedures contains <= 500 CFU/ml (recommendation)
Sterile coolant/irrigant solutions used during surgical procedures
Manufacturer's instructions for water quality are available and followed
Manufacturer's instructions for anti-retraction valve maintenance are available and followed
Dental Devices
Waterlines are turned on and flushed for at least 2-3 minutes at the beginning of the day, with handpieces disconnected

Dental devices that enter the mouth and are connected to the dental air/water system (including handpieces, air/water syringes, sonic/ultrasonic scalers, etc.) are flushed for 20- 30 seconds before removal for reprocessing
Sterile water is available and delivered from a source separate from the dental unit
Handpieces that can be removed from the air and waterlines are cleaned, lubricated and sterilized between patients
Handpieces that can be removed from the air and waterlines are maintained according to the manufacturer’s instructions
Suction lines are purged between patients by aspirating water or an appropriate cleaning solution
At least once per week, suction lines are flushed out with an enzymatic cleaner or appropriate cleaning solution
Respiratory assist equipment is cleaned and high-level disinfected between patient use
Other
Materials, impressions and intra-oral appliances are cleaned and disinfected prior to being sent to an off-site laboratory
All items returned from an outside laboratory to a dental office are cleaned and disinfected prior to placing in a patient’s mouth
On-site laboratories have a separate receiving area for contaminated items.
Laboratory equipment that becomes contaminated is cleaned and disinfected between patients (e.g., articulators, case pans, rubber bowls, spatulas, lathes, pressure pots, water baths)
